In this case, if the creature would die as a result of the damage, it instead falls unconscious and follows the rules for death saving throws ({@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB}) rather than dying outright.

entries.name: Optional Rule: It's Hard to Spare Lives
entries: When attempting a non-lethal attack or spell using this rule, your attack roll is made with disadvantage, and if the effect involves a saving throw, the target has advantage on its saving throw. This reflects the difficulty of subduing a target without dealing fatal damage and may make capturing enemies more challenging.

variantrule.name: Destroying Magical Barriers, and Similars
entries: Magical barriers, force creatures, and similar effects, such as Leomund's Tiny Hut, Tiny Servant, Arcane Gate, Wall of Force, Mordenkainen's Faithful Hound, and Arcane Eye, can be destroyed using magical weapons.
HP and AC: These effects have hit points equal to 30 times the spell level of their creation and an AC of 20. They are immune to Poison and Psychic damage, and fails all saving throws.

Destruction: Only magic weapons can damage them, with the required rarity depending on the spell level: Common (1st-level), Uncommon (3rd-level), Rare (6th-level), Very Rare (8th-level), and Legendary (9th-level).
DM Discretion: The DM may rule that some effects are more resistant or immune to specific magical effects or items.

variantrule.name: Coup de Grace
entries: You can use your action to attempt to execute a {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} or {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB} creature. Make an attack roll that automatically hits. Roll 1d4 to determine the outcome:

items: On a roll of 1–3, the creature dies instantly.
On a roll of 4, the creature takes the normal damage from the attack instead of dying.

entries: If the target is a player character or an important NPC, it only instantly dies on a roll of 1. Otherwise, it takes the normal damage from the attack.

entries.name: Optional Rule: Cinematic Only!
entries: The Coup de Grace can only be used in scenes outside of combat.

variantrule.name: Aimed Strike
entries: As an Action, you focus your next attack, taking time to aim. Your next attack roll until the end of your next turn have Advantage. After using Aimed Strike, your speed becomes 0 until the end of your next turn or until you make the attack.

variantrule.name: Death's Door
entries: When reduced to 0 hit points, a character can choose to enter 'Death's Door' instead of falling unconscious, remaining conscious but at risk of death.
While at Death's Door, taking damage causes one failed death saving throw, or two on a critical hit. A creature with three failed death saving throws dies.
Stabilizing a character at Death's Door only grants two successful death saving throws instead of actually stabilizing. Three successes restore the character to 1 HP and end Death's Door.

At the end of each turn, a character in Death's Door gains one level of exhaustion. They may choose to fall unconscious at this moment, ending Death's Door and following the usual rules for being at 0 hit points.

variantrule.name: Acadian Magic Rebalancing
entries: This is a group of changes, rebalancing and bans on spells for Acadia
This presumes the use of {@variantrule Alternate Spell Casting|CompendiumofAcadia}.
If a spell with the same name exists in more than one book, the PHB 2024 takes priority, if they are in different books the DM decides wich takes priority.

Spells  from Books Accepted: Player Hand Book 2024, Acquisitions Incorporated, Astral Adventurer's Guide, Fizban's Treasury of Dragons, Guildmasters' Guide to Ravnica, Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden, Strixhaven: A Curriculum of Chaos, Tasha's Couldron of Everything, The Book of Many Things, Xanathar's Guide to Everything, Dungeons of Drakkenheim, Tal'Dorei Campaign Setting Reborn, Humblewood Campaign Setting, Grim Hollow: Lairs of Etharis, Explorer's Guide to Wildemount, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish, The Gunpowder Codex e Firearms of the Realms.
NPC controlled by you having a magic item count against the number of magic items you can have active.

rows: Takes two turns to take effect; non-native creatures now have disadvantage.
Blade Ward ({@spell Blade Ward|XPHB} → {@spell Blade Ward|CompendiumofAcadia})
Grants +2 AC instead of +1d4 AC against attacks.
Conjure Minor Elementals ({@spell Conjure Minor Elementals|XPHB} → {@spell Conjure Minor Elementals|CompendiumofAcadia})
Nerfed the scaling to 1d8 instead of 2d8.
Now has upcasting and is better at handling spells of the same level.
Feign Death ({@spell Feign Death|XPHB} → {@spell Feign Death|CompendiumofAcadia})
Made it a little better against detection.
Find Traps ({@spell Find Traps|XPHB} → {@spell Find Traps|CompendiumofAcadia})
Greater Restoration ({@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} → {@spell Greater Restoration|CompendiumofAcadia})
Made it harder to get rid of curses.
Heat Metal ({@spell Heat Metal|XPHB} → {@spell Heat Metal|CompendiumofAcadia})
Added a new situation where the spell can end.
Hypnotic Pattern ({@spell Hypnotic Pattern|XPHB} → {@spell Hypnotic Pattern|CompendiumofAcadia})
At the end of each turn, the creature remakes the check.
Phantasmal Force ({@spell Phantasmal Force|XPHB} → {@spell Phantasmal Force|CompendiumofAcadia})
Can now be upcasted for more damage.
Protection from Energy ({@spell Protection from Energy|XPHB} → {@spell Protection from Energy|CompendiumofAcadia})
Advantage against effects that deal that damage.
Remove Curse ({@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} → {@spell Remove Curse|CompendiumofAcadia})
Made it harder to get rid of curses.
Casting time improved from Action to Bonus action.
Speak with Plants ({@spell Speak with Plants|XPHB} → {@spell Speak with Plants|CompendiumofAcadia})
Limited the amount of questions you can ask.
Spirit Guardians ({@spell Spirit Guardians|XPHB} → {@spell Spirit Guardians|CompendiumofAcadia})
Limited the saves to twice per round.
Zone of Truth ({@spell Zone of Truth|XPHB} → {@spell Zone of Truth|CompendiumofAcadia})
Added a new situation where the spell can end.
Consume Mind ({@spell Consume Mind|GHLoE} → {@spell Consume Mind|CompendiumofAcadia})
Made it more akin to other spells that recall information.
Magic Mirror ({@spell Magic Mirror|GHLoE} → {@spell Magic Mirror|CompendiumofAcadia})
Blade of Disaster ({@spell Blade of Disaster|TCE} → {@spell Blade of Disaster|CompendiumofAcadia})
Damage of each hit increased by 1d12.
Octarine Spray ({@spell Octarine Spray|DoDk} → {@spell Octarine Spray|CompendiumofAcadia})
Special cannot stack an infinite amount of times anymore.
Encode Thoughts ({@spell Encode Thoughts|GGR} → {@spell Encode Thoughts|CompendiumofAcadia})
Clarified how the memory is pulled.
Carven Rifle ({@spell Carven Rifle|GPCodex} → {@spell Carven Rifle|CompendiumofAcadia})
Sequoia Six-Shooter ({@spell Sequoia Six-Shooter|GPCodex} → {@spell Sequoia Six-Shooter|CompendiumofAcadia})
Banned: Their effects will be accommodated by items.
Banned: Spell is kind of a slog.
Banned: Too strong for a cantrip.
Invoke the Amaranthine ({@spell Invoke the Amaranthine|HWCS})

Revivify ({@spell Revivify|XPHB}), Raise Dead ({@spell Raise Dead|XPHB}), Reincarnate ({@spell Reincarnate|XPHB}), Resurrection ({@spell Resurrection|XPHB}), True Resurrection ({@spell True Resurrection|XPHB})
Banned: Resurrection is hard in Acadia; their effects will be accommodated by items.
Banned: Added Lesser Wish ({@spell Lesser Wish|CompendiumofAcadia}); the Wish effect will be limited to items.

entries.name: Additional Notes
entries: Mechanics Added or Changed:

rows: Inefficiency compensation. This cost must be paid to offset the spell's inefficiency. Alternatively, you can upcast the spell by 1 level to bypass this cost.
The spell works only if cast within the plane it was created. If used elsewhere, this restriction does not apply, and the additional cost is waived.

variantrule.name: Hyper-Class: Acadian
entries: The Acadian Hyper-Class is a special subclass granted by the DM on top of a character's normal class. These Hyper-Classes are intentionally powerful and designed for campaigns in the complex manyverse of Acadia.
You also have access to {@variantrule Pathfinder Mana System|CompendiumofAcadia}.

As part of this Hyper-Class, players create custom abilities in collaboration with their DM, which follow a progression of power similar to a wizard subclass. These abilities are unlocked at levels 3, 6, 10, and 14. Additionally, this Hyper-Class grants access to unique planar abilities, including the capacity to use {@spell Pathfinding|CompendiumofAcadia}.

entries.name: Level 1: Pathfinder
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the ability to cast the spell {@spell Pathfinding|CompendiumofAcadia} without a spell slot, and you always have it prepared. You can do so a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus.
These uses are replenished after completing a Long Rest, during which you must spend at least 1 hour in a process called Syphoning.

entries.name: Syphoning
entries: During Syphoning, you attune to the ambient flow of mana around you, entering a trance-like state. In this state, you experience vivid hallucinations of objects, creatures, and places that can be entirely imaginary or drawn from any time, place, or reality.
These visions might originate from your imagination, other worlds, alternate dimensions, or distant timelines.
This process strengthens your connection to planar energies, recharging your uses of your Pathfinder feature.

entries.name: Level 3: Acadian Latent Power
entries: At 3rd level, you awaken your first Acadian Latent Power, a unique ability tailored to your character's narrative and thematic elements. These powers are developed collaboratively with your DM and should align with the power level of a wizard subclass feature of the same level.

You gain additional Acadian Latent Powers at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels. Each power must use Mana as a fuel source. If the ability is passive, it must also include an optional feature or enhancement that consumes Mana to activate or function at a greater scale.

entries.name: Level 3: Forge Holy Weapon
entries: You can summon a sacred weapon associated with your deity. By using a Magic action, you conjure a melee martial weapon into existence. The weapon's damage die becomes {@damage 1d10} and it deals radiant damage instead of its usual type.
If the weapon is versatile or two-handed, it deals {@damage 1d12} damage when wielded with two hands.
After hitting a creature with this weapon, you can expend 1 {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} to deal an additional {@damage 2d8} radiant damage.

entries.name: Level 3: Reality Ripple
entries: You can momentarily shift through space, allowing you to teleport up to 15 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. This requires a bonus action and can be used a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus.
All expended uses are restored when you finish a Long Rest.
If you have no remaining uses, you can spend 1 {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} to regain a number of uses equal to half your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Level 3: Bad Omen
entries: You gain the Lucky feat, allowing you to reroll attack rolls, saving throws, or ability checks under certain conditions.
At the start of your turn, you can spend 1 {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} to extend your luck to others for 1 minute.
During this time, you can use your Lucky rerolls on attack rolls, saving throws, or ability checks made by any creature you can see within 30 feet.

entries.name: Level 3: Dark Blood
entries: When you roll initiative, you gain 5 temporary hit points as your vitality surges.
By expending 1 Red Mana, you can enhance this effect, gaining 15 temporary hit points instead.
Additionally, you can use a Magic action to spend 1 {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} and gain 10 temporary hit points at any time during combat.

entries.name: Level 3: Fury of the Forest Protector
entries: You can channel the raw strength of nature to empower your melee strikes. As a bonus action, you can change the mastery of your melee weapon to 'Push' for 1 minute. If you do not normally have access to weapon masteries, this feature grants you temporary access to the 'Push' mastery for the weapon you are wielding during its duration.

Additionally, you can spend 1 {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} when you activate this ability to deal extra damage if a creature is pushed into a wall or similar structure. For every 5 feet the creature is unable to move due to the obstruction, it takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage. At the DM's discretion, the wall or structure may also take the same amount of damage.

variantrule.name: Optional: Unshaped Class
entries: You start at level 0 as an Unshaped character, a flexible state before choosing a class. Use the following guidelines to create your Unshaped character:

entries.name: Unshaped Core Traits
entries: Primary Ability: None
Hit Points: 6 + your Constitution modifier
Weapon Proficiencies: Simple weapons
Proficiency Bonus: +2
Starting Attributes: 14, 14, 12, 12, 10, 8
Starting Equipment: One or two simple weapons of your choice, an Explorer's Pack, common clothes, one common or uncommon magic item, and 5 GP.

entries.name: Creating Your Character
entries: 1. Choose a Race: Select a race as per standard character creation rules.
2. Choose a Background: Pick a background for your character to determine skills, tools, and features.

entries.name: Unshaped Luck
entries: You have a unique ability that reflects the fluid nature of an Unshaped character. When you roll a d20 for a D20 Test, you can grant yourself Advantage on the roll. Alternatively, when a creature rolls a d20 for an attack roll against you, you can impose Disadvantage on that roll.
You can use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: Gaining a Class Level
entries: When an Unshaped character advances to 1st level, they must choose a class. This transition represents their training and specialization into a specific role within the adventuring group. Follow these steps:
1. You can choose to replace your 'Unshaped Luck' feature for an Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.
2. Gain all 1st-level features of the chosen class, except starting equipment. Adjust proficiencies, saving throws, and other abilities as per the class rules.
3. Replace your current hit points with the hit points granted at 1st level by the chosen class.

variantrule.name: Misc. Reactions
entries: This section introduces a set of extra reactions a creature can take. These reactions can be used at the start or end of an action on another creature's turn. They include:

items: Close Eyes: Use a reaction to close your eyes until the end of your next turn. This is meant for avoiding effects like a Medusa's Petrifying Gaze.

Focus Attention: Use a reaction to ignore a number of creatures of your choice until the end of your next turn. You are considered blinded to them but ignore them for effects that take advantage of your distraction with more than one creature, like Sneak Attack or Flanking.
Say Key Word: Use a reaction to say a key word that activates a specific effect. For example, this could trigger a {@spell Contingency} spell or a magic item that requires a verbal activation.

variantrule.name: Wheel of Destiny
entries: Some heroes rise and fall, but the Wheel of Destiny keeps spinning, weaving tales yet untold. Fear not! There is always a hero for the stories to find their voice!

The Wheel of Destiny is a mystical game of fate, played by beings of immense power to guide stories and influence the tides of destiny. In essence, it is a deck of cards, The Deck of Destiny, that channels the will of fate for those it deems worthy.
At the start of each session, players draw a card from the Deck of Destiny. At the end of the session, all cards are returned to the deck, and it is shuffled for the next cycle.

entries.name: Deck of Destiny Composition
entries: To use this mechanic, you’ll need a deck of playing cards. Assemble the deck as follows:
- 7 cards from each suit (Hearts, Diamonds, Clubs, Spades): 8, 9, 10, J (Jack), Q (Queen), K (King), and Aces.
- Add 2 Jokers.
This creates a custom 30-card deck for the Wheel of Destiny. Shuffle the deck after arranging it.

entries.name: Activation Rules
entries: Destiny Cards can be activated at any time. The player, not the character, activates the card. This means cards can still be used even if the character is unconscious or dead. If the GM allow, it can even be used in scenes where the player character is not present.
Instead of using the suit's effect, players may choose an effect from the 'Essential Use' list.
After activation, the card is placed in the discard pile. Once all cards have been used, a {@variantrule Wheel Of Destiny Spin|CompendiumofAcadia} occurs, and the deck is restored.

entries.caption: Effects
rows:
Heal twice the card’s value; or
Make a weapon attack (Aces grant an additional action instead of an attack); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level, expiring after a Long Rest.

Add the card’s value as a bonus to any d20 Test; or
Recover a spell slot up to 4th level (Aces recover a spell slot of any level); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level, expiring after a Long Rest.

Give disadvantage to a d20 Test made by a creature you can see (Aces make the creature roll an additional d20 and take the lowest result); or
After a creature takes damage, add damage equal to the card's value of the same type; or
Gain temporary {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level, expiring after a Long Rest.

Increase your AC by the card's value until the end of this turn; or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level, expiring after a Long Rest.

After knowing the result of a d20 Test, make it fail; or
Choose a specific result for a Luck Roll; or
Gain 1 temporary {@variantrule 🟣 Purple Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, lasting until the end of this turn.

Replace a d20 Test made by you with the card’s value (declare before rolling); or
Gain a {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}; or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level, expiring after a Long Rest.

variantrule.name: Additional Conditions
entries: This introduces new conditions:

items: {@condition Ablaze|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Steeled|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Confused|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Covered|CompendiumofAcadia}

variantrule.name: Alternative Magic Item Use
entries: Instead of attunement slots, every character can have up to 6 non-consumable magic items activated for use at any time.
To change which items are activated, you must spend an action to rearrange the magic items you are wearing or carrying. Only activated items can be used or provide their benefits.

If a class feature or ability grants additional attunement slots, it instead increases your number of items that can be active. For example, an Artificer feature that grants an additional attunement slot (4 instead of 3) allows you to activate up to 7 magic items instead of 6.

variantrule.name: Rush of Power
entries: You can push yourself beyond your natural limits through a surge of adrenaline or arcane power, but this comes at a significant cost to your body and mind.

items: Adrenaline Rush. When you fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can reroll the attempt. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per Long Rest.
Arcane Rush. As a spellcaster, you can regain a spell slot, with the spell slot level limited by your proficiency bonus. You can use this feature once per Long Rest.

entries: At the end of 1 minute, lethargy sets in. You gain levels of Exhaustion equal to the level of the spell slot regained through Arcane Rush, plus the total number of times you have used Adrenaline Rush.

You cannot use either feature if you have any level of Exhaustion. Additionally, the total Exhaustion levels you can accumulate from these features cannot exceed your proficiency bonus. If you reach this limit, you can no longer use these features until you finish a Long Rest.

variantrule.name: Pathfinder Mana System
entries: The Pathfinder Mana System governs the use and recovery of mana in the multiverse. Creatures capable of accessing mana can store an amount of mana equal to their level. Each round, they can spend an amount of mana equal to their proficiency modifier.

entries.name: {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}
entries: Green Mana is tied to elements, nature, growth, and the cycles of creation. It embodies vitality and the primal connection to the world.

Green Mana views reality as a product of the primordial forces that govern existence, each acting according to its inherent nature. These forces encompass balance, growth, and the unyielding will of nature.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Nature and intuition
Spirits, animals, and trees
Alchemy and natural processes
Manipulation of fire, water, air, earth, electricity, sound, and metals

entries: Green Mana's manifestations are primarily elemental, invoking the divine forces of nature. These manifestations reflect a belief in a reality shaped by the interplay of greater natural forces.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Primordial spell list 🌿
Evocation school spells ✨

items.name: Elemental Damage Associations
items: Fire: Fire damage 🔥
Air: Electric damage ⚡
Earth: Acid damage 🧪
Water: Cold damage ❄️
Interactions with spirits and nature-based entities
Healing and medicinal applications
Use of poisons and acids

entries: Green Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, representing its ability to foster growth and vitality against entropy and decay. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, as order and rationality can constrain its primal and untamed nature.

entries.name: {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}
entries: Blue Mana represents self-reference, essential forms, paradoxes, and the manipulation of magical instructions. It is deeply tied to the recognition of patterns and a Gnostic understanding of reality.

Blue Mana views reality through a syncretic lens, perceiving all things as fundamentally the same in essence. Differences are seen as interpretations or distortions of a common form, emphasizing unity and interconnectedness.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Self-reference and essential forms
Recognition of patterns and paradoxes
Countermagic and spell manipulation
Gnosticism and syncretism
Arcane perception of reality's underlying structures
Unbiased magical instructions as the foundation of all spells

entries: The primary manifestation of Blue Mana is through essential patterns. These patterns reveal the underlying structures of all things, acting as a self-referential force that unveils the arcane truths of existence.

Blue Mana is also fundamentally tied to the creation and manipulation of magical instructions. Every spell uses Blue Mana as the instructional core that defines its function, making it the purest form of unbiased magic. This neutral essence can be shaped or biased by other mana types, channeling their specific properties.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Countermagic spells ✨
Force damage
Spells that alter or disrupt patterns
Abilities that manipulate time, flow, or causality
Understanding and revealing hidden truths
Perception and reconfiguration of magical forms
Force damage as a manifestation of pure magical energy

entries: Blue Mana is neutral and does not participate in the oppression cycle. It often serves as a stabilizer or mediator, ensuring balance among the other mana types.

entries.name: {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}
entries: Black Mana is associated with entropy, death, time, and the inexorable decay of all things. It embodies the inevitability of the void and the silent, inert end of existence.

Black Mana views reality as a process destined for constant entropy and eventual cessation. It thrives on the cycles of life and death, wielding power over decay, anti-life, causality, unrealized potential, and the manipulation of chaos and gravity.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Forces of time, space, and entropy
Decay, necromancy, and anti-life
Causality and unrealized potential
Darkness, inertia, and immobility
Cycles of life and death
Graviturgy (manipulation of gravity)
Chaos as a fundamental force

entries: The primary manifestation of Black Mana is through the forces of movement. These are profane powers that manipulate the fundamental forces governing time, space, gravity, and decay. This perspective sees reality as an inevitable march toward entropy and the void.

While Black Mana is often associated with evil, its nature is more apathetic than malevolent. Its historical association with taboo practices—such as manipulating life and death—has led to its stigmatization and misuse for dark purposes. This misunderstanding has fueled its reputation for villainy, but Black Mana is, at its core, a neutral force of inevitability.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Necromancy school ✨
Chronomancy and time manipulation
Graviturgy and gravity-based effects
Effects that drain or transfer life energy
Spells tied to darkness and immobilization
Manipulation of decay, destruction, and chaos

entries: Black Mana is oppressive toward {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, consuming its passion and vitality with inevitable decay. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters its entropy with growth and renewal.

entries.name: {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}
entries: White Mana is rooted in order, rationality, and mental discipline. It governs laws, knowledge, oaths, and the power of the mind to shape reality through structure and rules.

White Mana views reality as a construct of the mind, where the act of observing, naming, and defining creates a framework for existence. It thrives on the enforcement of structure through contracts, laws, and mental discipline.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Order, rationality, and mental discipline
Contracts, laws, and oaths (including devil’s contracts)
Spells and powers tied to genies and wishes
Reality as a mental construct shaped by observation and rules
Transcendence through discipline and structure

entries: The primary manifestation of White Mana is through psychic forces and conceptual powers that impose order on the chaotic. These include the power to create and enforce agreements, from divine pacts to devil's contracts, as well as granting powers through oaths and the granting or fulfillment of wishes, such as those from genies.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Divine spell list 🙏
Enchantment spells ✨
Abilities tied to contracts, laws, and oaths
Spells that enforce agreements or compel actions
Powers that stem from oaths, such as genie-granted wishes
Contracts with supernatural entities, including devils

entries: White Mana oppresses {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} by overriding natural chaos and primal growth with mental constructs and rationality. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters its rigidity and structure with raw emotion and passion.

entries.name: {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}
entries: Red Mana reflects passion, emotion, and willpower. It fuels the raw, unfiltered power of creativity, destruction, and the manifestation of one's inner strength.
Red Mana views reality as a canvas for emotion and will, where desires and passions are the forces that shape the world. It thrives on chaos, change, and the direct realization of personal goals.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Emotion, passion, and raw willpower
Musculature and regeneration
Biological and blood manipulation
Manifestation of emotions in physical form (e.g., demons)
Chaos, unrestrained creativity, and transmutation
Grounding in physical reality and its malleability

entries: The primary manifestation of Red Mana is through Martial Arts ⚔️, a discipline that channels the user's willpower into superhuman feats. These arts combine refined technique with an individual's raw determination to turn their objectives into reality. Though not inherently magical, Martial Arts harness the power within the practitioner, making the impossible achievable through sheer will and mastery.

Creatures made of manifested emotions, such as demons, are often shaped and molded by Red Mana. These beings are the physical embodiment of raw emotional energy, given form and intent through this primal force.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Destructive spells fueled by passion
Fire magic and pyromancy 🔥
Blood magic and biological manipulation
Abilities tied to raw emotion and personal willpower
Martial techniques that achieve superhuman feats
Transmutation spells that reshape physical reality

entries: Red Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, breaking through its rigid structures with raw passion and chaos. However, it is oppressed by {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which consumes its vitality and passion with entropy and inevitability.

entries.name: Regras de Opressão

variantrule.name: 🟢 Green Mana
entries: Green Mana is tied to elements, nature, growth, and the cycles of creation. It embodies vitality and the primal connection to the world.

Green Mana views reality as a product of the primordial forces that govern existence, each acting according to its inherent nature. These forces encompass balance, growth, and the unyielding will of nature.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Nature and intuition
Spirits, animals, and trees
Alchemy and natural processes
Manipulation of fire, water, air, earth, electricity, sound, and metals

entries: Green Mana's manifestations are primarily elemental, invoking the divine forces of nature. These manifestations reflect a belief in a reality shaped by the interplay of greater natural forces.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Primordial spell list 🌿
Evocation school spells ✨

items.name: Elemental Damage Associations
items: Fire: Fire damage 🔥
Air: Electric damage ⚡
Earth: Acid damage 🧪
Water: Cold damage ❄️
Interactions with spirits and nature-based entities
Healing and medicinal applications
Use of poisons and acids

entries: Green Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, representing its ability to foster growth and vitality against entropy and decay. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, as order and rationality can constrain its primal and untamed nature.

variantrule.name: 🔵 Blue Mana
entries: Blue Mana represents self-reference, essential forms, paradoxes, and the manipulation of magical instructions. It is deeply tied to the recognition of patterns and a Gnostic understanding of reality.

Blue Mana views reality through a syncretic lens, perceiving all things as fundamentally the same in essence. Differences are seen as interpretations or distortions of a common form, emphasizing unity and interconnectedness.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Self-reference and essential forms
Recognition of patterns and paradoxes
Countermagic and spell manipulation
Gnosticism and syncretism
Arcane perception of reality's underlying structures
Unbiased magical instructions as the foundation of all spells

entries: The primary manifestation of Blue Mana is through essential patterns. These patterns reveal the underlying structures of all things, acting as a self-referential force that unveils the arcane truths of existence.

Blue Mana is also fundamentally tied to the creation and manipulation of magical instructions. Every spell uses Blue Mana as the instructional core that defines its function, making it the purest form of unbiased magic. This neutral essence can be shaped or biased by other mana types, channeling their specific properties.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Countermagic spells ✨
Force damage
Spells that alter or disrupt patterns
Abilities that manipulate time, flow, or causality
Understanding and revealing hidden truths
Perception and reconfiguration of magical forms
Force damage as a manifestation of pure magical energy

entries: Blue Mana is neutral and does not participate in the oppression cycle. It often serves as a stabilizer or mediator, ensuring balance among the other mana types.

variantrule.name: ⚫ Black Mana
entries: Black Mana is associated with entropy, death, time, and the inexorable decay of all things. It embodies the inevitability of the void and the silent, inert end of existence.

Black Mana views reality as a process destined for constant entropy and eventual cessation. It thrives on the cycles of life and death, wielding power over decay, anti-life, causality, unrealized potential, and the manipulation of chaos and gravity.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Forces of time, space, and entropy
Decay, necromancy, and anti-life
Causality and unrealized potential
Darkness, inertia, and immobility
Cycles of life and death
Graviturgy (manipulation of gravity)
Chaos as a fundamental force

entries: The primary manifestation of Black Mana is through the forces of movement. These are profane powers that manipulate the fundamental forces governing time, space, gravity, and decay. This perspective sees reality as an inevitable march toward entropy and the void.

While Black Mana is often associated with evil, its nature is more apathetic than malevolent. Its historical association with taboo practices—such as manipulating life and death—has led to its stigmatization and misuse for dark purposes. This misunderstanding has fueled its reputation for villainy, but Black Mana is, at its core, a neutral force of inevitability.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Necromancy school ✨
Chronomancy and time manipulation
Graviturgy and gravity-based effects
Effects that drain or transfer life energy
Spells tied to darkness and immobilization
Manipulation of decay, destruction, and chaos

entries: Black Mana is oppressive toward {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, consuming its passion and vitality with inevitable decay. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters its entropy with growth and renewal.

variantrule.name: ⚪ White Mana
entries: White Mana is rooted in order, rationality, and mental discipline. It governs laws, knowledge, oaths, and the power of the mind to shape reality through structure and rules.

White Mana views reality as a construct of the mind, where the act of observing, naming, and defining creates a framework for existence. It thrives on the enforcement of structure through contracts, laws, and mental discipline.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Order, rationality, and mental discipline
Contracts, laws, and oaths (including devil’s contracts)
Spells and powers tied to genies and wishes
Reality as a mental construct shaped by observation and rules
Transcendence through discipline and structure

entries: The primary manifestation of White Mana is through psychic forces and conceptual powers that impose order on the chaotic. These include the power to create and enforce agreements, from divine pacts to devil's contracts, as well as granting powers through oaths and the granting or fulfillment of wishes, such as those from genies.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Spells from the Divine spell list 🙏
Enchantment spells ✨
Abilities tied to contracts, laws, and oaths
Spells that enforce agreements or compel actions
Powers that stem from oaths, such as genie-granted wishes
Contracts with supernatural entities, including devils

entries: White Mana oppresses {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} by overriding natural chaos and primal growth with mental constructs and rationality. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters its rigidity and structure with raw emotion and passion.

variantrule.name: 🔴 Red Mana
entries: Red Mana reflects passion, emotion, and willpower. It fuels the raw, unfiltered power of creativity, destruction, and the manifestation of one's inner strength.
Red Mana views reality as a canvas for emotion and will, where desires and passions are the forces that shape the world. It thrives on chaos, change, and the direct realization of personal goals.

entries.name: Core Themes
items: Emotion, passion, and raw willpower
Musculature and regeneration
Biological and blood manipulation
Manifestation of emotions in physical form (e.g., demons)
Chaos, unrestrained creativity, and transmutation
Grounding in physical reality and its malleability

entries: The primary manifestation of Red Mana is through Martial Arts ⚔️, a discipline that channels the user's willpower into superhuman feats. These arts combine refined technique with an individual's raw determination to turn their objectives into reality. Though not inherently magical, Martial Arts harness the power within the practitioner, making the impossible achievable through sheer will and mastery.

Creatures made of manifested emotions, such as demons, are often shaped and molded by Red Mana. These beings are the physical embodiment of raw emotional energy, given form and intent through this primal force.

entries.name: Associated Features
items: Destructive spells fueled by passion
Fire magic and pyromancy 🔥
Blood magic and biological manipulation
Abilities tied to raw emotion and personal willpower
Martial techniques that achieve superhuman feats
Transmutation spells that reshape physical reality

entries: Red Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, breaking through its rigid structures with raw passion and chaos. However, it is oppressed by {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which consumes its vitality and passion with entropy and inevitability.

variantrule.name: Luck Rolls
entries: Luck Rolls are rolls made when an event's outcome is determined primarily by luck or chance, rather than skill or direct action.
These rolls can include modifiers but are not considered d20 Tests.
An example of a Luck Roll is determining whether a Wand of Magic Missiles breaks after expending all charges. Or the roll made for choosing witch Ray the beholder will shoot

variantrule.name: Reflex, Fortitude, and Will
entries: Saving throws are replaced with 'Reflex, Fortitude and Will'. They are determined by the highest value of two ability scores, reflecting different aspects of a character's resilience:

items: Reflex: The highest between Dexterity and Intelligence.
Fortitude: The highest between Constitution and Strength.
Will: The highest between Wisdom and Charisma.

entries: When a class provides proficiency in two saving throws from different categories, the player chooses only one. For example, a Sorcerer (proficient in Constitution saves and Charisma saves) instead must choose proficiency in either Fortitude or Will.

variantrule.name: Enhanced Foods
entries: Specially prepared foods provide adventurers with unique benefits during their journeys.

A creature can only have one food effect active at a time. If a creature consumes another food that grants a food effect, it must choose whether to keep the current effect or replace it with the new one.
There are two types of foods:

items: Snacks: Can be consumed with a bonus action and provide short-term benefits.
Meals: Require at least 10 minutes to consume but offer more lasting and impactful effects.

entries: Here are some example foods and their effects:

entries.caption: Enhanced Foods
rows: Gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
You have advantage on the next saving throw you make until the end of your next turn.
You gain a +1d4 bonus to your next attack roll made within 1 minute.
You gain 10 feet of additional movement until the end of your next turn.
When spending Hit Dice during a rest, add +1d8 to the total recovered.
Gain a 1d6 to add to an ability check using Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution. This pool refreshes after a long rest.
Gain a 1d6 to add to an ability check using Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma. This pool refreshes after a long rest.
For the next hour, you gain advantage on Constitution saving throws to resist exhaustion or environmental effects (such as extreme heat or cold).

variantrule.name: Universal Spell Scrolls
entries: When Scribing Spell Scrolls, a spellcaster can choose to make it a Universal Spell Scroll. This type of scroll can be used by any creature that can understand any language, even if the spell is not on their spell list.

If the creature does not have a spell list, or if the spell on the scroll is of a higher level than they can normally cast, they must make the ability check for casting it as described in the Spell Scroll rules. If the creature is not a spellcaster, they may choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma for the check.

A creature can spend 1 hour familiarizing itself with a spell scroll and its casting process. If it does so, it adds its proficiency bonus to the ability check made to cast the spell. This familiarity lasts until the creature takes a Long Rest.

variantrule.name: Rest Quality
entries: This rule assumes the use of Slow Natural Healing from {@variantrule Healing|DMG}.
The quality of the location where characters sleep impacts the effectiveness of their {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, as described below:

entries.caption: Rest Quality Effects
rows: All Hit Dice are treated as rolling a 1.
A dirty, unsanitary place, worse than camping with a bedroll. May involve extreme cold or heat, with food being of extremely poor quality or unavailable.
Recover half the hit points normally restored by spending Hit Dice.
Sleeping on the ground with minimal cover or bedding. Access to low-quality or insufficient food.
Recover hit points from Hit Dice as normal.
A well-prepared campsite with adequate bedding, warm clothing or blankets, and access to standard rations or normal food.
Roll additional Hit Dice equal to your proficiency bonus.
Staying in a comfortable inn or a similar environment, with good food and a warm, safe place to sleep.
Roll additional Hit Dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.
Sleeping in a castle or similarly lavish environment, with the finest food, drinks, and accommodations.

variantrule.name: Alternate Spell Casting
entries: All spells require both verbal and somatic components. Rules regarding material (M) components remains the same.

variantrule.name: Grappling Spellcasters
entries: If a creature is {@condition Grappled}, {@condition Prone}, or {@condition Restrained} and attempts to cast a spell that requires somatic components, it must succeed on a DC 15 Concentration check. On a failure, the spell does not take effect, and the spell slot is not expended.

condition.name: Ablaze
entries: The creature is engulfed in flames and takes 5 fire damage at the start of each of its turns. The creature can use its action to muffle and extinguish the flames, ending the condition.

condition.name: Steeled
entries: The creature is wearing metal armor or clothing. Attacks that deal electric damage have advantage against a Steeled creature, and the creature makes saving throws against effects that deal electric damage with disadvantage.

condition.name: Confused
entries: The target can't take Bonus Actions or Reactions and must roll {@dice 1d10} at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn, consulting the table below.

rows: The target doesn't take an action, and it uses all its movement to move. Roll {@dice 1d4} for the direction: {@b 1}, ↑ north; {@b 2}, → east; {@b 3}, ↓ south; or {@b 4}, ← west.
The target doesn't move or take actions.
The target doesn't move, and it takes the {@action Attack} action to make one melee attack against a random creature within reach. If none are within reach, the target takes no action.

condition.name: Covered
entries: The creature is covered in a substance, typically liquid. When Covered, specify the substance (e.g., Covered (Oil), Covered (Water)). The DM determines additional properties for specific substances. Examples:

items: Oil: If the creature takes Fire damage, it takes an additional 5 fire damage.
Water: If the creature takes Electric damage, it takes an additional 5 electric damage.
